Whether it's to "have" or "let's see",
the “whys”, whether it goes together,  separated, with an accent, without an accent...
Let's see what are the mistakes we make the most when we speak or write in Spanish,
and the tricks to avoid making them with the help of a linguist.
Hello, hello... I am teacher Mónica, creator of educational content on spelling and grammar.
We start with the verb "haber", which is one of the most versatile and,
at the same time, one of the ones that generates the most confusion.
Do you know why?
The verb "haber" functions as a main and auxiliary verb and,
at the same time, can accompany two verbs at the same time. For example, “we have been eating.”
We have the verb "have", "we have", "stated" from the verb estar and "eating" from the verb comer.
It is a verb that is usually conjugated incorrectly. As an auxiliary, it accompanies other verbs
in compound tenses: I have gone, you will have eaten, I had called.
When "have" is the main verb, it is impersonal,
that is, it does not have a specific subject. For example: “There is bread” or “There were several girls.”
Fair enough, a common mistake is to say, for example, “there were several girls” and conjugate everything in
the plural. In reality, it is not plural because this verb is impersonal and has no subject.
It is complex to think that a verb cannot be pluralized when it
is accompanied by a plural subject, but it is a mistake.
And just with the “hay” of the verb "haber" there always appears a great confusion with
other words that sound similar, but are written differently: "there", "hay" and oh!
"There" is an adverb of place.
"There" is the impersonal form of the verb "haber."
And oh! It is an interjection that serves to express everything from pain to joy.
A classic phrase to distinguish them is: “There is a man who says: Oh!”
Another of the most common errors when
writing with the verb "haber" is to confuse "haber" with "to see".
This is the verb in the infinitive and "to see" is a preposition and a verb.
For example: We are going to watch a movie tomorrow. Let's see.
This is because they are homophonous expressions or words, which sound the same,
but are written differently.
Let's go with an example: there is "as", which is the letter or a prominent person;
"has", from the verb "have", or "do", imperative of "do", like: do the task.
To differentiate them, here's a trick:
If there is a word that follows that “has” and it ends in -ado, -ido,
like "finished", "asleep". Or it suddenly
ends in -to, like "put". Or in -cho, "said
" . those that go with "v" and "b". Or,
as we would say in Mexico, with "v" for cow and "b" for donkey.
The thing is that Spanish speakers increasingly distinguish the difference between one and the other,
but originally they were pronounced differently.
For example, between "bello" and "vello", from beautiful and hair. "Herb" or "herb",
"herb" (small plant) or "hierva" (from the verb to boil). "Throw away" and "vote." "Throw"
to throw something or throw it, and "vote" to cast a vote.
Speaking of pronunciation, in general,
in Latin America when we speak the "z", "c" and "s" are not distinguished.
For example: laziness, grass and health. Although they sound the same, one goes with "z",
another goes with "c" and another goes with "s". Be careful, the joke is not pronouncing it, but writing it well.
And here I'm going to tell you a super common mistake: adding an "s" where it doesn't belong.
How do you think you say: “Did you eat paella or did you eat paella?”
It is without "s".
Well, it is often confused because in almost all conjugations in the second
person the verbs end with "s", for example: you come, you ate, you came.
I'm going to tell you a trick so you know the mistake: when we use "tú",
followed by the verb conjugated like this, it never ends in "s". You went, you ate, you lost.
Ok, it was clear to me, but let's go with another error: the confusion of the whys.
Let's go one by one, so that it is clear to us:
Why: separated and with an accent. It is used for direct or indirect questions.
Why did you eat my taco? Why did you do it, Alicia, why did you eat my taco?
Because: together and without accent. Very easy, used for answers to why questions.
But it is also often used to introduce subordinate clauses that express cause.
I ate the arepa because I was hungry.
Why: separate and without accent. It can be the preposition "by" + the pronoun "that." And,
on the other hand, preposition "for" + the subordinating conjunction "that."
As in the phrase: In the end they decided not to show up.
We have three. Let's go with the last one.
Why: together and with an accent. It is a masculine noun that means “cause,
motive or reason” and is written with an accent because it is an acute word ending in a vowel.
For example: I don't understand the reason for your attitude [= the reason for your attitude].
Everything has its reason [= its cause or its motive].
How many things, Alicia? Well, yes, we make mistakes and we don't even realize it.
Well, we're not done yet because we still have the punctuation marks left.
Although I see signs that say Free!!!! With a thousand signs,
only two are correct, the one that opens and the one that closes. Both in question and in admiration.
And there are also times when we are afraid of the point.
A trick for using it: if it sounds like the idea is ending,
use a period. If the sentence continues, use a comma.
And a great trick for commas is to pay attention to the intonation. If it sounds like a brief pause, it's a comma.
And speaking of commas, Alicia, explain the vocative comma, please.
My favorite comma, one of the most forgotten. It is used when we speak directly to someone.
For example, if I say: “Peter sweeps,” I say that Pedro is sweeping. But if I say:
“Peter, sweep,” I tell Pedro to start sweeping.
It should also be used when we greet or address someone:
Good morning, Sergio.
Happy birthday, Ana María.
My condolences, Antonia.
Shut your eyes! We all forget the comma of the vocative.
And see if it's important... Because saying:
"Let's eat, children" is not the same as "Let's eat, children."
And so we finish our list of the most common mistakes we make in Spanish.
